items.author: Jason Matthew
items.description:
We all know that a website and an online presence are essential parts to owning a business, a brand, or in general living in this modern age. Heck I have multiple websites between my personal website, my business website, and a few side projects, and I bet you probably doÂ too.

Thatâ€™s not why youâ€™re here today though. Youâ€™re here because you want to learn what more you need to do to make your websites great! Well Iâ€™m here to tell you that you need multiple things for a great website and that these are all going to vary depending on who youÂ ask.

Ask a SEO expert whats most important for a website and heâ€™ll say SEO. Ask a designer whats most important and he will say something that will roughly translate to â€œgood designâ€ whether it be UX, UI, or some other form or design. Ask a developer and he will tell you that neither of these things matter if your websites code is wonky, if it doesnâ€™t functionÂ right.

So what am I here to tell you that these three disciplines wont? Well thatâ€™s simple. Theyâ€™re all right. Thatâ€™s right you need all of these things and many others to get the most out of yourÂ website.

Often youâ€™ll see people spend thousands of dollars on the design and development of their website but nothing on the promotion or marketing ofÂ it.

You will have to excuse my ignorance of fine art here. But do you think that the Mona Lisa, painted by Leonardo da Vinci. One of, if not the worlds most famous painting would be worth as much if after da Vinciâ€™s death in 1519 whoever inherited this painting shoved it in a closet along with the rest of Leonardoâ€™s paintings never to be seen by the world again? I doubt it, sure I imagine at some point someone would have found them dragged them out and put them on display but I doubt it would be as famous or worth as much as it isÂ today.

We arenâ€™t here to talk about paintings though. We want to talk about website. What I am really trying to get at here is that you need a well rounded approach to your website. Spending thousands of ğŸ’² ğŸ’² ğŸ’² on a designer and developer will do you no good if no one sees your website. Likewise a brilliantly marketed website with thousands of visitors every day hitting it will never be as effective if itâ€™s design, and user experience is horrible. It should be noted here that if your business sucks none of these things will help, a website and marketing canâ€™t make up for a poor product orÂ plan.

So what am I saying to do? Simple a two step approach to yourÂ website.

Step 1

Figure out who your market is and design your website to capture their attention. You should probably have a solid idea of who your customers are and what they are looking for. Give your designer as much of this information as you can and if they are any good, pretty soon you will have a website that both looks good and captures your audience / clients attention. Donâ€™t skimp on your developer either, sure it should be nice and simple but a good developer will ensure that your website works for years to come and doesnâ€™t just break with the next update that comes along. They will also ensure that everything is modular and well documented, making sure that in the future changes and even changing your developer will be a painlessÂ process.

Step 2

Great you have a awesome looking website, it functions well and is designed to capture your markets attention. Now the most important thing you can do is to market it. There are so many ways of marketing a website that diving into each of them in this article would be useless. I am sure that a quick Google search will provide you with hundreds of options. Donâ€™t get overwhelmed here though look through all your options and chose three maybe four of them to master, and then get to work. A web agency might help you with these but there is no way if you have simply paid an up front cost of $X for your website that they will keep doing this indefinitely. Sure they might set up some basic SEO and do a little marketing to begin with but without a monthly fee you can be sure they arenâ€™t doing anything. So you either need to do this yourself or get someone on board whoÂ will.

Finishing up

So with those two steps done you should be set. Knowing both sides of the story will help you and your business grow like never before. Youâ€™ll have a website that doesnâ€™t look like rubbish and actually converts those that land on it, and you will actually have real humans looking at it to be converted. With these things done youâ€™re set to bust into the bigÂ leagues.

Marketing WebsiteÂ Template

items.title: How to Speed Up Your Website in One Easy Step
items.author: Jason Matthew
items.description:
So you want a faster website? Well I am about to blow your mind with how quick and easy it is to make your website lightning fast! Oh and did I mention we are going to do this in just oneÂ step?

Ok well maybe one step is a little bit of an exaggeration, but trust me itâ€™s going to be quick, easy, and painless.

First thingâ€™sÂ first

Head on over to cloudflare.com and sign up for an account. Pretty easy so farÂ right?

Next up

Youâ€™ll be asked to enter a website address. This should be the address of the website you want to speedÂ up.

Cloudflare will scan your name records and work its magic! and once thatâ€™s finished you are on yourÂ way.

Double Check

Alright this is the tricky bit and you better pay attention now. You will be shown a bunch of DNS records like the picture below. You need to make sure that the scan Cloudflare just did captured all of the records you have attached with your current DNS provider. Iâ€™d recommend logging into your DNS provider and double checking them against each other. If you skip this and a record is missing, you can be certain that some part of your website, emails, or business is going to beÂ broken.

Moving to Cloudflare

So you have made sure all your DNS records are there right? Great! Youâ€™re all set to move on and get started using Cloudflare. Follow their instructions for setting up their name servers with your name register. They have great guides and do a much better job than I could. Once this is done you are set. The name server change will slowly spread to all the DNS servers, like that rumor you started in high-school. Once it has finished spreading you are set. Youâ€™re using Cloudflare.

A few thingsÂ left

Alright so youâ€™re set up with Cloudflare but weâ€™re not done yet. Thereâ€™s 3 more things I want you to do to ensure that your site is superÂ fast!

  1. Minify
  2. Cache
  3. Page Rules

When we have these three things done you know your site will be loadingÂ fast!

1. Minify

First things first I want you to head on over to the speed tab in your dashboard and make sure that you are auto minifying all your JS, CSS, and HTML. All this will do is strip out any unnecessary characters like comments from your data and squish it all onto less lines. This just helps these resources use less space, and less space means faster transfers!

One big thing to watch out for is with the minification and especially the JS minification, sometimes if your code isnâ€™t quite right the minification process will break it and you might need to dig around a little for thatÂ ; youÂ missed.

2. Caching

Pay attention as this one is important. First before we play with any of these settings we are going to need to understand them a little first. The two settings on the cache tab that I want you to pay attention to are Browser Cache Expiration, and CachingÂ Level.

Browser Cache Expiration, this is how long a browser will keep your website files locally. Now this is where you are going to have to decide for yourself how long is right for you and your website. For me I have mine set for 1 day as I donâ€™t have a lot of return visitors, you either get in touch with me about your project or you find someone else, you donâ€™t come back that often. I could set it longer but I am always playing with little tweaks here and there on my site and if I change anything in the CSS and JS that is cached by a local machine, that my site requires to work properly. Youâ€™re going to see a messed up site or just nothing at all. Not a great look for a front endÂ dev.

If your site was a large news publication however you might want to set it longer as you have visitors coming back pretty often, hopefully daily. You also probably arenâ€™t changing the look of your site as often. So you can let people keep the cached content longer, maybe a month orÂ so.

The next setting on this page we should look at is the caching level. This requires us to know a little about query strings. A query string would look something like http://jasonmatthew.me/form?name=jason This doesnâ€™t actually do anything on my site but hopefully you get the idea. It tells the web server to do something with some information in the url. A common example of this is in the WordPress search functionality.

Now we know what a query string is we have to decide what to do with them. Cloudflare gives us three options. If you donâ€™t know 100% that your website doesnâ€™t use query strings I would suggest that you leave this on standard.

Cloudflare again has some really good documentation on this to take a look at if youâ€™re not sure or want to learnÂ more.

3. PageÂ Rules

This is where things get tricky. Below you can see my three page rules. We only want to pay attention to the first one however. In this we set the url to our site jasonmdesign.com/* where the * denotes anything. so everything will be cached. This means that all of our pages will be cached on the Cloudflare edge servers and on the users browser. Here you can also change these settings specifying the TTL or time to live for these cached resources.

Again I will use the example of a news site here, because you are adding articles every few hours, or at least every day you probably donâ€™t want to cache your home page or your blog page. To do this you could setup a page rule that looked something like jasonmdesign.com/blog/* this would only cache the articles in blog/ but not the blog itself assuming the blog is your homeÂ page.

Finishing up

With these setting changed you are well on your way to speeding up your site. Go and double check that all of these changes havenâ€™t effected anything. A pro tip for this is to use the incognito option in your browser as this will eliminate and caching that has happened and show you what a brand new visitor would see and experience loading your site for the firstÂ time.

I hope you have found this helpful, feel free to comment below if you have any questions, need a hand with setting this up, or just want to sayÂ hi.

Now there is of course the import functionality of medium where a post will get brought into the system and then linked back to your original site or wherever it came from. This is good but not ideal, if you have to manually do it for every article youÂ write.

A better option provided weather you are using WordPress or another CMS platform or even a static site generator like Jekyll is to use some form of plugin to automatically preform the import functionality whenever you publish a new post. This is a better alternative, but still not quiteÂ there.

Your first instinct might be to tag a â€œlatest?format=jsonâ€ query onto the end of your user or publication, but this isnâ€™t going to help us much. While it will get the JSON that we need. Think about it, you go to sleep one night with 80% of your clients coming from Facebook, and the rest word of mouth. You donâ€™t have a website because your Facebook page has been working fine for you. You wake up in the morning with an email letting you know Facebook has canceled your account. Another example, one that has actually happened to me. Your working through a third party marketplace. items.title: Why Web Professionals need to go outside.
items.author: Jason Matthew
items.description:
Lately I have been thinking about marketing my own web design and development agency, Iâ€™ve looked at all of the online avenues. While researching these it made me realise something very important. They have almost no barrier to entry for web professionals. This low barrier to entry for particular markets is exactly why you need to goÂ outside.

Barrier to entry, what isÂ it?

The best way I can describe a barrier to entry is by describing a scenario. Imagine there is this beautiful park, where all our friends and family are playing. You naturally want to go and play there with them too. Unfortunately there is something stopping you. A huge fence with no way around. You either have to climb over, or dig under. This fence is your barrier to entry for theÂ park.

Barriers to entry arenâ€™t just for parks though they could be for anything. Take tertiary education for example, a barrier to entry for many students is their grades during high school, or another barrier could be their financial situation. Both of these can be overcome but they make it a little harder for everyone to go to University or college. These are barriers toÂ entry.

Why a barrier to entryÂ matters?

So to illustrate a barrier to entry I have thought of a scenario. Well two scenarios in fact, both very similar in many aspects but with a few slight changes that make all the difference.

Scenario 1

You visit a market on the weekend, there are store owners and itâ€™s generally a great atmosphere. The store owners yell out about the great deals they are offering and their amazing products. Some owners selling amazing pottery, other the most beautiful jewelry, and even others selling the finest foods. Itâ€™s a great atmosphere, you come here often and make purchases every now andÂ then.

Scenario 2

Similar to scenario 1 you are at a market. This time itâ€™s different though, the store owners are all selling exactly the same things. They all say that their thing is different to the others, better even. They describe the differences in words you donâ€™t really understand but know are important. They even try and show you the difference but you still canâ€™t really see it more than just the superficial impact that it has. Itâ€™s not a very enjoyable for you or forÂ them.

Where you fitÂ in.

Thinking about these scenarios, and about web professionals. The barrier to entry for a web professional to advertise online is so low that every web professional is doing it. It ends up as a market place with everyone selling essentially the same thing, which just confuses buyers even more. There is a reason that 80% of web professionals find their clients through referrals. Itâ€™s because they have distinguished themselves from the crowd by being trusted by a thirdÂ party.

Now Iâ€™m not saying that the only way for web professionals to market is through offline means, because itâ€™s not. Marketing online can be very effective if done right. But the emphasis needs to be on the done right, not on being done half baked with some good ideas thrown into the mix, youâ€™re wasting yourÂ time.

So go spend some time outside, and meet some new people. Or even meet with some new potential clients. What are you waitingÂ for?

items.author: Jason Matthew
items.description:
This is a quick tutorial on how to sync the Atom code editor setup between PCâ€™s running windows. Using dropbox or any other cloud storageÂ service.

Using a laptop that I can take between clients work and home is great, but I also love the benefits that a standard desktop offers me. So I use both as I am sure many many others do. I do front-end development and design, thatâ€™s my job. I rely on my code editor for daily tasks. Switching between two PCâ€™s with slightly different configurations is an annoyance that I donâ€™t want to dealÂ with.

I used a sync extension for Atom which helped the problem greatly and saved me a lot of time. This worked well but it wasnâ€™t a perfect solution. My plugins would need updating on both computers whenever I fired up Atom. Some settings for whatever reason just didnâ€™t copy across with the syncÂ plugin.

This is why I decided to come up with my own better solution to the problem. The technique I am going to describe can be used for a many of apps and programs, so keep it in mind for other problems like thisÂ also.

What youâ€™llÂ need

  • Dropbox (or another cloud storage service) set-up on bothÂ PCâ€™s
  • SymLink Creator (this can also be done in command prompt but I have found the GUI to be extremely helpful) which can be foundÂ here
  • Long Path Eraser (This may not be needed but itâ€™s a useful tool to be aware of anyway) foundÂ here
  • A zip tool like 7Â Zip

What we are going to beÂ doing

The idea behind what we are doing is pretty simple. If you have done any research into this topic before I am sure you will have come across similarÂ methods.

We are going to be moving the Atom packages, settings and extensions folder to our cloud storage (Dropbox). Then linking the default locations for this on both computers to this oneÂ folder.

Moving theÂ File

To start our process we need to move the Atom folder from its current location. It is kept in your userâ€™s current directory. On windows, an easy shortcut to get here is to paste the following code into the bar in any explorerÂ window.

%UserProfile%

This in your userâ€™s directory you should see a file titledÂ .atom this is the one we need. I had to use 7 Zip to compress the folder to copy it across to Dropbox, as the file paths were too long to use the normal copy-paste operation.

I zipped the file and then moved the zipped file over to Dropbox. It doesnâ€™t matter where you place the file in Dropbox but I prefer somewhere that makes sense and is out of theÂ way.

From here you will need to extract the folder making sure to select the option â€œextract toÂ .atom/â€. This will add your folder to Dropbox which will keep it in sync forÂ us.

This is where the magic happens. We are going to link the old file path to the new path that will be in sync. This will need to be done on both computers.

The first thing we need to do is delete the oldÂ .atom folder. For me because the file path names were too long. I needed to use the Long Path Eraser Tool at this point because the file names were too long for windows to handle natively. If you have different settings on the two PCâ€™s only the settings and extensions from the copied folder will beÂ kept.

After deleting the oldÂ .atom folders in your user directories, fire up SymlinkÂ Creator.

In the link folder section, you are going to need to put the file path that we took the originalÂ .atom folder from. For me, this was C:\Users\Jason. You will also need to name the linkÂ .atom

In the destination folder, you will need to put the path to the folder in Dropbox. Remembering that these paths may be different on your different PCs.

Double check that you have selected â€œfolder symbolic linkâ€ as the type at the top, and symbolic link in the destination folder down theÂ bottom.

From here you can simply click create a link and thatâ€™s it youâ€™re finished. Remember that this needs to be done on both computers.

items.author: Jason Matthew
items.description:
Today I was talking with a friend in a Slack community that I am a part of. He is working on building his first custom WordPress website. I was talking with him about how he was doing it, and how I have built websites in the past. The topic turned to the plugins he was using. As it would be the tools he was using were similar to those I had used to buildÂ sites.

We talked about them, and I shared how I had included Advanced Custom Fields with my theme. I felt it made a more concise and eloquent solution than having to install the plugin when the theme was installed. He had never heard of doing this, and I remember it took me a while to figure out how to do this myself. So in the hope of lessening someoneâ€™s learning curve, I am sharing with youÂ now.

So to get us started, why would you want to include a plugin with a theme rather than installing it separately? Well, there are arguments for and against, I will just talk about why I made my choice. I think a plugin that adds functionality and is essential to the theme you are building should be included with it. If itâ€™s needed for the theme to function then you would never have an instance with the theme installed and not the plugin, so it seems silly to have to installÂ both.

As I walk you through this process I will be using the advanced custom fields plugin as an example, but the process should be similar if not the same for other plugins too. If you donâ€™t know what Advanced Custom Fields is, you should. Every WordPress developer at some stage has used it, wanted to use it, should have used it, or will useÂ it.

So letâ€™s get started. First off you are going to need to get the plugin downloaded you can do this from the WordPress plugin directory. Or from the advanced custom fieldsÂ website.

With this downloaded, we need to extract the contents of the zip file and place it somewhere within the theme folder. For me, I chose /inc/plugins I also renamed the advanced custom fields folder to just ACF to make it easier to reference later.

With the contents of the plugin installed we need to include the main php file of the plugin in the functions.php of ourÂ theme.

To do this we go to add some code to our functions.php (Obviously)

// 1. customize ACF path add_filter(â€˜acf/settings/pathâ€™, â€˜my_acf_settings_pathâ€™); function my_acf_settings_path( $path ) { // update path $path = get_stylesheet_directory() . â€˜/inc/plugins/acf/â€™; // return return $path; }

This first bit of code changes the path for the advanced custom fields settings. Notice the only part that you will need to change from this is the $path variable, where â€˜/inc/plugins/acf/â€™ should represent your folder structure.

The next section of code we add does a similar thing to that above except it changed the location of the directory for ACF. Again the only part that requires changing is the $dir path to represent your folder structure.

// 2. customize ACF dir add_filter(â€˜acf/settings/dirâ€™, â€˜my_acf_settings_dirâ€™); function my_acf_settings_dir( $dir ) { // update path $dir = get_stylesheet_directory_uri() . â€˜/inc/plugins/acf/â€™; // return return $dir; }

These two parts of code above are specific for advanced custom fields and for other plugins may not be required, or they may require different filters to be passed toÂ them.

This next piece of code will be similar if not the same for including every plugin within your theme. In it we actually include the main php file of the plugin. In this case that is acf.php. Here again you will need to change the code to match your folder structure, and the name of the php file we are including to match whatever plugin it is that you are including.

// 3. Include ACF include_once( get_stylesheet_directory() . â€˜/inc/plugins/acf/acf.phpâ€™ );

If all this has gone well you should be able to save your functions.php and reload your browser and have advanced custom fields included with yourÂ theme.

items.title: WordPress Speed Optimization
items.author: Jason Matthew
items.description:
WordPress speed optimization is crucial to you and your websites success, however it is often overlooked. When a website loads slowly the sites visitors become impatient and this leads to an overall bad impression and experience. Today however I want to share a few things that I have found to improve page load times and overallÂ speed.

A GoodÂ Host

A web host is the foundation for your website, it is the bedrock that everything else is built upon. Without a good web host you are very unlikely to make big differences in your websites speed, however it is still possible to make some improvements to your websitesÂ speed.

How to find a good web host? This question gets a little harder to answer in a broad sense, because there is no one size fits all answer to this question. There is no one best web host because every website is different and itâ€™s this difference that means that you will need to decide based on factors for yourself which is best. Factors such as price, support, speed, and services like backups and emailÂ options.

A good web host will also take care of a lot of things that you would otherwise have to do like website caching, compressing and use of a content deliveryÂ network.

So with that said, Flywheel is the host that I use because they are able to supply a super fast server optimized for WordPress, and take care of a lot of the finer details of speed optimization. Sure there are cheaper hosts with more options but they fit exactly what I need. A Fast web host with a focus on helping web designers and their clients to receive the best possible service that they can. Visit theirÂ website.

Good Code

To me good html, css, js and php is something that should be optimized for every website. It is a shame to see a beautiful website that has un-optimized code, although this is rarely the site owners fault but related back to the designer and developer. Optimizing website code is simple and easy when you know what you are doing however without thought at the beginning of a project it can be a big hassle toÂ fix.

So for you as a user there isnâ€™t a whole heap of optimization that you can do for this without an in-depth knowledge, however there are still things that you can do. A must have in my opinion is JS & CSS Script Optimizer. This is a WordPress plugin that optimizes these parts of your website for you automatically. There are other plugins out there that do the same thing but this is the only one that I have found that has worked for me every time I have used it. This plugin combines all the css and javascript that your website uses into a single file for each and then removes anything that is unnecessary from these files so that they are as small as possible and thus load as fast as possible.

Another thing that I like to do when creating websites is I make sure that if I am using any third party css or js like bootstrap or JQuery that I use the scripts from their CDN network as this is a much faster way to fetch these file than from off your ownÂ server.

Image Optimization

Images can make a website much slower if they are used incorrectly with file sizes upwards of 2mb for some images it would be ridiculous to use a 4000 x 2600 image on a website. So how do you fix this? Well what I like to do is first before the images ever get uploaded to my website I make sure that they are at an acceptable size, one that will offer a good quality image but keep the image size to a minimum. To do this I use Photoshop and use the export as function and play around with sizes and file formats until I find something that works well. As a general rule of thumb though I like to make sure that for a high quality image I donâ€™t go bigger than 1920 x 1080 and aim for under 300kb in size. This is relatively easy to achieve while still having a high qualityÂ image.

On top of this optimization I use a plugin called ewww image optimizer this plugin comes in two flavors a cloud based service and a server-based one. I use the cloud based optimization allowing less load to be placed on the web server that I use. The cloud option does cost a small sum of money but it is well worth the initial investment.

Plugins

After talking about a few plugins above I wanted to share a little more here about them. Never use a plugin for simple functionality, this will always slow down your website. Let me repeat that, avoid using plugins as much as possible. Before you install a plugin thing really hard about if you actually need it and what benefit you are actually gaining fromÂ it.

Some plugins are necessary or even essential but the majority of them are used to add things to your website that arenâ€™t essential and sometimes donâ€™t even add any value to your site. I have never made a website that I have needed more than 10 plugins. This is including the basics like the two described above along with SEOÂ plugins.

So basically what I am saying is if you need it add it but unless its vital to your website it will probably be doing more harm thanÂ good.

Testing

The last thing that you should do when optimizing your WordPress website for speed is test it. I like to use both Pingdom and GTmetrix these are both online websites that allow you to test the loading times of your website, they also suggest changes that you can make to your website that would help improve theseÂ metrics.

So to wrap up you need to start with a great web host like Flywheel, then make sure that your web designer or developer is thinking about speed from the beginning. After that you want to make sure that you are optimizing the images, css and js for the fasted load times possible. On top of this you should be carefully thinking about the plugins that you install on your website. Then once these things are done test your website. See how much it has improved and check if there is anything else that you can do to Optimize your WordPress websiteÂ more.
